revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Syed Ahmed | honorific_suffix = | image = Syedahmed.JPG | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | native_name = সৈয়দ আহমেদ | native_name_lang = bn | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|09|17|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Sylhet]], [[Bangladesh]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = | nationality = [[British Bangladeshi]] | other_names = | ethnicity = [[Bengali people|Bengali]] | citizenship = | alma_mater = [[Sir John Cass Redcoat School]],
[[Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College|Hammersmith College]] | occupation = [[Businessperson|Businessman]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = Candidate on ''[[The Apprentice (UK)|The Apprentice]]'' | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = [[Islam]] | denomination = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | awards = | website = {{URL|http://www.syed-ahmed.com/}} | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Syed Ahmed''' ({{lang-bn|সৈয়দ আহমেদ}}; born 17 September 1974) is a British [[entrepreneur]], [[Businessperson|businessman]] and [[Celebrity|television personality]] of [[British Bangladeshi|Bangladeshi origin]].{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2006/nov/01/mediamonkey |title=Monkey goes to the National TV Awards |publisher=Guardian |date=2006-11-01 |accessdate=2009-05-02 |location=London}} He is the founder and CEO of the British design and manufacturing hand dryer company SAVortex. He is best known for his 2006 appearance in the [[The Apprentice (UK Series Two)|second UK series]] of the [[BBC]] [[reality television]] show ''[[The Apprentice (UK)|The Apprentice]]''. ==Background== Ahmed was born in [[Sylhet]], [[Bangladesh]].{{cite web |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/film_and_tv/s/203/203701_sugar_begins_hunt_for_new_apprentice.html |title=Sugar begins hunt for new Apprentice |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2006-02-08 |author=Ian Wylie |accessdate=2008-08-26}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/5270904.stm |title=Media troubling Apprentice stars |publisher=BBC News (BBC) |date=2006-08-21 |accessdate=2009-05-01}} When he was nine months old,{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/related_reports/article1265205.ece?token=null&offset=0&page=1 |title=Apprentice star gets a taste for the high life (Page 1) |publisher=The Sunday Times |author=Ali Hussain |date=2006-08-21 |accessdate=2009-06-09 |location=London}} he moved with his parents to England and was brought up in [[East (London sub region)|East London]]{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/article56816.ece |title=Yes, Ahm so happy |publisher=The Sun |date=2006-07-22 |accessdate=2009-06-10 |location=London}}{{cite web |url=http://www.newagebd.com/2008/oct/10/oct10/xtra_inner4.html |title=British Bangladeshis who have made a mark |author=Tamara Zaman |publisher=New Age Xtra |date=2008-10-16 |accessdate=2009-05-02}} in a devout Muslim family.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-436491/My-love-Syed-tore-apart.html |title=My love for Syed tore me apart |author=Michelle Dewberry |publisher=The Daily Mail |date=2007-02-19 |accessdate=2009-05-02 |location=London}} He attended the [[Sir John Cass Redcoat School]] in [[Stepney]] from the age of 11 to 17 achieving 7 [[GCSE]]s. He then attended the [[Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College|Hammersmith College]], where he achieved a [[Business And Technology Education Council (BTEC)|BTEC]] in [[Business]] and [[Finance]]. He later managed restaurants, including the Titanic, part of the White Starline Group, owned by [[Marco Pierre White]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2006/02_february/07/apprentice_boys.shtml |title=The Apprentice series two meets the boys |publisher=BBC (Press Office) |date=2006-07-02 |accessdate=2009-06-09}} He was in the [[Air Training Corps]] and dreamed of becoming an [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] [[Aviator|pilot]] but decided to go into business instead.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-400186/Yes-Apprentice-parents.html |title=Yes we're Apprentice parents |author=Natalie Clarke |publisher=The Daily Mail |date=2006-08-11 |accessdate=2009-05-02 |location=London}} Ahmed is currently the [[CEO]] of SAVortex, which specialises in high-speed, energy efficient [[hand dryers]].{{cite web |url=http://www.savortex.com/pdfs/syed_ahmed_ceo.pdf |title=Syed Ahmed, Chief Executive Officer |publisher=SA Vortex |accessdate=2009-05-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Ahmed's development of the SAVortex technology was shown in an hour-long documentary, ''Hot Air'', broadcast on [[Sky Digital (UK & Ireland)|Sky]]. Ahmed initially financed the business himself.{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/realitytv/a61323/syed-ahmed.html |title=Syed Ahmed |author=Nick Levine |publisher=Digital Spy |date=2006-02-18 |accessdate=2008-10-16}} Ahmed was a director of the [[Information technology|IT]] [[recruitment consultancy]] firm ''IT People'' until May 2006, and a director of Magenta Partnerships Limited from June 2006 until February 2007. He has made speeches to the young business enterprise community,{{cite web |url=http://www.youngchamber.com/CaseStudy-detail.asp?csid=14 |title=Report on Isle of Wight Young Chamber Conference 2006 |publisher=Young Chamber |year=2006 |accessdate=2009-05-01}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web |url=http://www.tuduloo.co.uk/mcc/mcc4.html |title=University of Oxford Special: Oxford University’s Trading Places |publisher=MCC |date=2008-04-28 |accessdate=2009-05-02}} and the more general enterprise community in Britain.{{cite web |url=http://www.youngchamber.com/CaseStudy-detail.asp?csid=14 |author=Dan Storey |title=Syed Ahmed |publisher=Herts Connections |date=2008-09-08 |accessdate=2009-05-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==''The Apprentice''== {{Further|The Apprentice (UK series two)}} Ahmed appeared as a candidate in [[The Apprentice (UK Series Two)|series two]] of ''[[The Apprentice (UK)|The Apprentice]]'', a British reality television show hosted by [[Alan Sugar|Lord Alan Sugar]]. The series was broadcast from February to May 2006. On the show Ahmed was a member of the "Invicta" team. He was a notable candidate on the show. One of his quotes on the show was a, ''£100,000 salary is not enough but it's a good place to start''."{{cite book |last=Haigh |first =Gerald |title=Inspirational, and Cautionary Tales for Would-be School Leaders: Tales for Would-be School Leaders |publisher=Routledge |year=2008 |pages=138}} ==Post Apprentice== Ahmed appeared on [[Sky News]] as a paper reviewer – reviewing current and forthcoming newspapers in a celebrity panel. He also has appeared on interviews, at [[BBC Breakfast]] with candidate [[Jo Cameron]] on the [[BBC]],{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/breakfast/4755687.stm |title=You're fired... |author=BBC Breakfast |publisher=BBC |date=2006-05-10 |accessdate=2009-06-10}} and also at [[GMTV]] on [[ITV]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23363969-details/Apprentice+star+'protecting'+Michelle+from+media/article.do |title=Apprentice star 'protecting' Michelle from media |publisher=Evening Standard (London) |date=2006-08-21 |accessdate=2009-06-10}} He appeared on [[Sky One]]'s program called ''[[The Match (Sky One TV series)|The Match]]'', where 80 celebrities take part to win a place in a celebrity football squad.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-400859/Badgers-big-idea-lands-TV-show.html |title=Badger's big idea lands her a TV show |publisher=The Daily Mail |date=2006-08-16 |accessdate=2009-06-10 |location=London}} Ahmed again appeared on another [[Sky One]] show, called ''[[Cirque de Celebrité]]'' (from October 2006), featuring celebrity circus acts, and he was voted off in the second week. He subsequently returned as a guest judge.{{cite web |url=http://www.virginmedia.com/tvradio/galleries/realitytv/apprentice2008/best-worst-candidates.php?ssid=2 |title=Best and worst of The Apprentice - Syed Ahmed |publisher=Virgin Media |accessdate=2009-05-02}} A Sky One documentary (from June 2007) called, ''Syed Ahmed - Hot Air?'', featured Ahmed attempting to launch a new company which specialised in hand and body dryers, with £20,000 of his own money, to develop in three months.{{cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/reality_tv/26569/Syed-pays-for-body-warmer.html |title=Syed pays for body warmer |author=Leigh Holmwood |publisher=The Sun |date=2007-04-26 |accessdate=2009-06-09 |location=London}}{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/culture/tvandradioblog/2007/jun/20/lastnightstvsyedahmedhot |title=Last night's TV: Syed Ahmed - Hot Air? |author=Lucy Mangan |publisher=Guardian |date=2007-06-20 |accessdate=2009-06-09 |location=London}}{{cite web |url=http://www.twofourbroadcast.com/syed-ahmed.asp |title=Syed Ahmed - Hot Air |publisher=Twofour Broadcast |accessdate=2009-06-09}} The program followed the launch of the SA Vortex's hand dryer products.{{cite web |url=http://www.abfed.co.uk/index.asp?p=News-And-Events&s=News-And-Events-Archive&a=45 |title=Syed Ahmed - Hot Air |publisher=Asian Business Federation |author=Louise Snell |accessdate=2009-06-09}} In December 2010, Ahmed was a host at the [[Spice times]] Restaurant Awards in Essex Romford.{{cite web|url=http://www.spicetimes.co.uk/spice-times-awards-press-release/ |title=Syed Ahmed Host |publisher=Spice Times Publishing Ltd |author=Spice Times Press Release |accessdate=2010-12-31}} ==Charity work== In 2008, Ahmed organised and led a race in support of a breast cancer charity.{{cite web |url=http://static.cityrace.co.uk/pdfs/apprentice.pdf |title=Sir Alan Sugar's Apprentices Line Up For The 2008 Standard Chartered Great City Race In Aid Of Breakthrough Breast Cancer |publisher=Standard Chartered |date=2008-07-08 |accessdate=2009-05-02}} He also sends money to families and charities located in Bangladesh. Ahmed was one of the four contestants with [[Secret Millionaire]]s, who attended the Geared for Giving campaign to help promote the Workplace Giving, on May 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.gearedforgiving.com/campaign-news/apprentices-and-secret-millionaires-get-geared-for-giving/ |title=Apprentices and Secret Millionaires get Geared for Giving |publisher=Geared For Giving |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2009-06-10}} Ahmed also took part in a charity relay to raise money for children in [[Gaza]]. Gaza100, was held on 24 May 2009 in [[Mile End Park]], east London, attracting over 1,500 people, which included also Apprentice candidates, [[Ghazal Asif]] and [[Tre Azam]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8065753.stm |title=Charity relay sets world record |publisher=BBC News (BBC) |date=2009-05-24 |accessdate=2009-06-07}} ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United Kingdom|Bangladesh}} *[[British Bangladeshi]] *[[Business of British Bangladeshis]] *[[List of British Bangladeshis]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.syed-ahmed.com/ Official Website] *{{twitter|syedahmed}} {{The Apprentice UK}} {{Persondata | NAME = Ahmed, Syed | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Businessman | DATE OF BIRTH = 17 September 1974 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Sylhet]], [[Bangladesh]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahmed, Syed}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British Muslims]] [[Category:Bangladeshi emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:British people of Bangladeshi descent]] [[Category:Bangladeshi businesspeople]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:The Apprentice (UK) candidates]] [[Category:Participants in British reality television series]] [[Category:People from Sylhet]] [[Category:People from London]] [[bn:সৈয়দ আহমেদ]]
